data.text: Contents
Introduction
Although this situation is rare it does constitute a major incident and must be  managed effectively.
The identity of newborn babies must be confirmed by two identity bands in accordance with policy. Children's wards put one identity band on to identify their patients.

Children visiting any of the Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust sites (‘the Trust'); or attending the outpatients or Accident and Emergency Departments with a parent or guardian remain the responsibility of the accompanying adult.
Scope
To ensure consistent and uniformed approach to dealing with this type of incident
To promote team working which is vital in this situation
To liaise effectively with outside agencies i.e. police, 0-19 safeguarding teams, media etc.
To achieve safe repatriation of baby/child with parents/guardian in the event of attempted abduction
It is a requirement for all Trust personnel to wear the approved Trust security
badge. Any staff unknown to the ward/department personnel must have their
reason for access ascertained and authorised.
The scope of this policy covers; the missing baby/child, attempted abduction and actual abduction of a baby/child.
Definitions
The definition of ‘abduction' is the criminal act of taking someone away by force or d
Roles and responsibilities within the Trust
Women and Children's Management Team
Will receive the findings/monitoring report and be responsible for ensuring the actions are completed.
Chief Executive has overall responsibility for ensuring that the Trust meets its statutory obligations and that effective security arrangements are in place and periodically reviewed.
Head of Security should ensure that all security staff are aware of actions required when a baby/child is abducted.
Security Team
Security guidance and awareness of Trust security procedures will be made available to all staff on induction.
Further specific security training or guidance will be made available by the Security Department on request.

CCTV cameras will be installed in specific areas throughout the hospital site for the prevention of crime and public safety. The cameras are monitored by Security Control 24/7. Data is held on servers complying with the ICO (Information Commissioners Office) guidance and data protection compliance.
Associate Director of Women and Children's Services has responsibility for ensuring that systems are in place and Staff are aware of procedures and how to access this policy.
All Staff
It is the duty of staff to be alert to the potential for baby/child abduction from hospital premises.
Staff must be alert to the following:
Any individual demonstrating undue interest in a baby or child that is with another parent
Personnel within areas without identification or purpose
Uniformed personnel without the Trust identification badge
Persons exhibiting suspicious or bizarre behaviour
Persons seen using fire or side exits in preference to the main thoroughfare
Persons embracing/hugging bags with obvious care
NB In the event of any of the above incidents, staff must intervene/challenge.

It is paramount that staff challenge any persons behaving in a suspicious manner, or who are unable to justify their presence within the area. The challenge should not be confrontational, but initially should take the form of a polite enquiry followed by tactics to delay if concerns are not allayed.

Security personnel should be quickly alerted by means by telephone. All ward staff must be quickly summoned to assist. The police may be required to apprehend the individual. Staff must not use physical restraint which may endanger their own safety.
Roles when a baby/child is abducted
Attempted Abduction of baby/child
5.1.1  If a member of staff witnesses the attempted abduction of a baby/child the following actions must be taken:
Delay the individual if possible by talking to them
Attempt to retrieve the baby/child if this can be done without causing physical harm to anyone
Call security and position staff at all exit routes.
Inform Clinical Site coordinator and departmental leads
Site co-ordinator should then inform Senior Manager on call and Communication Department (in case of media attention)
When the baby/child is safe, the Paediatrician must check the baby/child and return baby/child to parents.
Document all actions and complete the Trust incident form using Datix
Inform Nurse Specialist for Child Protection and the Child Safeguarding Team.
Offer debriefing to all staff involved
On report/discovery that a baby/child is found to be missing the following steps must be followed:
Report to Nurse/Midwife in charge who will then coordinate the situation initially
Obtain fundamental details of the missing baby/child i.e. appearance, where last seen etc. (see Appendix 1)
Instigate thorough search of the immediate area, recording areas searched (see appendix 2)
Alert security for urgent assistance, if possible place member of staff at entrance and exits to monitor movement in and out of area (see Appendix 3)
Ring 999 to summon the police.
Keep all patients at bedside unless clinical indications for being moved.
If baby/child found return with parents as soon as possible.
Complete incident form using Datix and collate relevant documentation.
Offer primary debriefing to parents and staff.
Staff/Parents may need further formal counselling.
Nurse/Midwife in Charge
5.3.1  Must co-ordinate the search of the area, notify the security services, site co- ordinator, on call general manager and on call medical staff:
Organise/Co-ordinate a full search of all hospital premises and grounds as soon as possible via security control centre
Ensure that parents/guardians are fully informed at all times
Ensure that all exits are fully manned
Protect the scene of abduction for Police examination
Identify a room for Police operations
Ensure that there is a complete list of patient and staff names and addresses
MATERNITY only: If available utilise the newborn baby photo service (such as Bounty) in conjunction with Police.
Direct all media enquiries to Communications dept.
Inform General Practitioner, Community Midwife, Health Visitor, Social Worker as appropriate.
Ensure that all documentation is complete and accurate including Trust incident form.
When incident finally resolved debrief all staff concerned, offer Trust counselling via occupational health if appropriate.
Inform HOM if patient on the maternity ward, Associate Director of Nursing for Paediatrics, Clinical Director and Associate Director
Switchboard Operator
5.4.1  Ensure that immediate contact is made with Police, Security, On-call manager and Executive Director on Call as requested.
Security Officers/ Porters
5.5.1  Have responsibility for securing all exits to the building and all exit traffic barriers. They will also liaise with the Police where necessary.
Senior Manager and Duty Matron On Call
5.6.1 Will assume the role of Incident Co-ordinator until the arrival of the Police. The Police will then assume that role, with the on call manager remaining as the Trust Incident Coordinator.
5.6.2 The on call manager will ensure an IMR form is completed for urgent referral to the Executive Review Group (ERG) who will decide on the need for a serious incident (SI) investigation.

5.6.3 Request that Security retain all CCTV recordings including previous 48hrs to abduction. Data retained on servers complying with the ICO (Information Commissioners Office) guidance and data protection compliance.
Communications Department Manager
5.7.1  Is responsible for all media/press enquiries and will liaise with the Police Press Office
Post incident review

The Associate Director for Women and Children's Services must conduct a post-incident review covering all aspects of action taken, including raising staff awareness and establishing further deterrent and preventative measures.
This review will address both the successful and unsuccessful elements of the incident. As part of the incident review, compliance with this policy will be assessed.

The objective will be to ensure that plans remain comprehensive and relevant and, above all, are understandable and operable by all staff. Views should also be taken from the Police, if they have been involved in the incident, with regard to the effectiveness of any proactive and reactive measures in place.

The Associate Director for Women and Children's Services will ensure a report is produced describing the issues arising from the incident and any actions needing to be taken to rectify any shortcomings in the Trusts procedures. The report will be submitted to the Trust Quality Governance Group.

Where the incident review has identified deficiencies, recommendations and action plans will be developed and changes implemented accordingly. Progress on these will be reported to the Associated Director of Women and Children's Services who will be responsible for the coordinating the implementation.
Monitoring and audit
Each document must outline the Trust's process of monitoring compliance with, and the effectiveness of the document's main points.
As a minimum all procedural documents must include the process for review/monitoring of all the related requirements within the NHSLA Standards.

Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Women's and Children's Practice steering groups which are the specialist group with the authority to approve local policies and guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the relevant staff in the Women's and Children's Services of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.

Appendix 4: Action card  - nursing/midwifery staff
Action during incident
Secure the area to prevent anyone from leaving the Ward.
Conduct an immediate search of the area and head count of babies/children and parents
Thoroughly check the Ward / Department and all areas in the immediate vicinity, e.g. lift/lobby areas.
Liaise with Police, Security, Nurse in Charge, On Call Manager to ensure effective communication and team working
If the Parents/visitors of the missing baby/child are present in the Ward / Department ascertain the last time they baby/child was seen and fill in baby/child identifier (Appendix 1)
All other patients/visitors on the Ward/Department should be asked for relevant information.
Appendix 5: Action card  - switchboard operator
On receipt of a security call summoning the assistance of security for a potential abduction of a baby/child. The Switchboard operator must note the following details from the Emergency call:
Name of the caller
Extension number of caller
Location from where baby/child is missing
Last time baby/child was seen
Contact Security
Contact the Police on 999, with message:
“baby/ child is missing and has possibly been abducted from the site” Connect the Police to the Ward from which the baby/child has been reported missing
The Switchboard Operator will notify the Site Coordinator and On Call Manager (out of hours or in hours Head of Department).
Baby/child Abduction Security Alert
Ward?
Baby/child? (name given only if known)

Every attempt must be made to contact the above.
